  • Be more MOBILE – do more on more device types (tablets, phones, wearables, etc.)
  • GUIDE me better – help me navigate my day
  • COLLABORATE better – support working across onshore/offshore teams, for example using Microsoft Teams Integration.
  • RESPOND faster – use Joule skills to speed up simple tasks, get fast info from search
  • REACT faster – get notified of business situations early
  • Be more PROACTIVE – use analytics and predictive models to trigger action
  • Be more AUTOMATED – use Joule agents to speed up complex tasks
  • Be more ADAPTABLE – make the most of Clean Core techniques to adapt to changing business needs

Hint: The UX Value Goal App Selection Guides are provide as a zipped file of 9 short PDFs. 

And finally:

  • Quick Guide for Fit Evaluation – Find the easy ways to adjust apps and features to your business needs. Hint: The Quick Guide for Fit Evaluation is provided as a PDF.

 

Where to find the UX Adoption Accelerators – Step by Step

You will find the accelerators referenced in several of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition roadmaps.  

Find all the roadmaps in SAP for Me in the SAP Activate Roadmap Viewer at: https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer

Select Explore All Roadmaps to find and mark your favourites.

Example: SAP Activate Road Map Viewer page showing the Explore All Road Maps button. Favorite roadmaps are shown for SAP Activate SAP Cloud ERP  Private.

 

The SAP Activate roadmaps for SAP Cloud ERP Private (i.e. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition ) contain many UX Adoption accelerators and content tasks.

Select the tag User Experience to find the UX Adoption accelerators.

Example screenshot showing the Accelerators tab in the SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private - System Conversion roadmap. The tag User Experience is selected in the left-hand pane - and includes a count of the accelerators found. In the right pane the accelerators are listed by Activate phase.

 

The accelerators are shown by phase. Simply select the links to download the accelerators you want to use.

Example screenshot highlighting the links to the accelerators in the Accelerators tab of the SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private - System Conversion road map.

You can also search across SAP Activate to find accelerators using SAP Joule. You can get quick information on related tasks, and AI-powered insights on making the most of these accelerators.

Example screenshot of showing using the SAP Activate search with keyword ux adoption.  AI-Powered Insights are shown for the selected roadmap giving quick guidance on how to use the accelerators, followed by the Search Results with links to accelerators.

 

FAQ

Do I have to wait for our next project to get value out of the accelerators?

No. You can use the content whenever you need to build awareness, encourage further adoption, and plan next steps.

Do I have to be using SAP Activate methodology to use these accelerators?

No. 

How you run your project is up to you and your partner.  Some SAP partners have their own methodology based on SAP Activate. 

Some customers use simple mini-sprints to grow adoption - you can example of a mini-sprint plan in the SAP User Experience Strategy Template. 

However you run your project, these accelerators are provided to help you confidently introduce User Experience, collaboratively make UX adoption decisions with your business stakeholders, and successfully bring a new way of working to your business users.

Do I have to run a workshop to use the templates?

No. For example:

  • You can select slides and demo videos from Establish the Business Value of UX to explain SAP Fiori to your long-term SAP GUI users.
  • You can refer to the App Selection Guide Be more MOBILE to find what apps make sense to use on smaller devices
  • You can refer to the App Selection Guide Be more AUTOMATED to understand how to find available SAP Joule Agents and what you need to create custom-built Joule Agents.

Can I get AI to help me select apps?

Yes!

In the UX Adoption: Scope the Future Workshop Template you will find some brief examples of using SAP Joule for Consultants to get advice. For example, “is there a Fiori app for <this task> in SAP S/4HANA <your release”.

You can even use AI to help you capture requirements in SAP Cloud ALM.  Have a look at AI Goes CALM: AI-Assisted Requirement Generation

Becoming a SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA guru

entry.title: SBTi Forest, Land, and Agriculture (FLAG) in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
entry.content:
As companies work towards meeting their climate targets, the distinction between fossil and land-based emissions is becoming increasingly relevant. Emissions from forests, land, and agriculture (FLAG) follow fundamentally different dynamics than those from fossil fuels and materials. FLAG emissions have a significant share in global greenhouse gas emissions, play a critical role in climate mitigation, biodiversity protection, and food system resilience, which provides several advantages in environmental impact mitigation within value chains.

However, these emissions are often bundled together with Fossil GHG Emissions within corporate inventories without the level of detail to credibly manage them. This makes it difficult for companies to set realistic targets, assess progress, or transparently communicate the role of land-based emissions and removals within their GHG inventories. 

When properly understood as part of the natural carbon cycle, FLAG emissions become an important part of net-zero strategies: They are governed by biological processes that allows them to interact directly with removals and carbon storage within shorter timeframes compared to Fossil emissions. 

Against this backdrop, the latest updates to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management mark a significant evolution from a single-impact focus to a holistic environmental footprint analysis. The new capabilities expand impact coverage and explicitly distinguish between fossil and biogenic emissions and removals, enabling companies to reflect land-based dynamics more accurately. 

 Why distinguishing FLAG emissions matters at corporate and product level 

Distinguishing FLAG emissions from Fossil emissions is not just an accounting exercise. At the corporate level, separating FLAG from non-FLAG emissions allows companies to determine whether they are required to set dedicated FLAG targets under certain criteria and to incorporate mitigation pathways that reflect the realities of land-based systems.  

At the Corporate level, this differentiation enables a more realistic target setting, prevents the inappropriate use or double counting of removals within corporate inventories, supports transparent reporting, and progress toward emissions reductions. Without this separation, land use impacts can get hidden behind corporate totals, making progress appear stronger than it actually is.

Within a corporate level inventory, consistently separating FLAG emissions within Scope 3 improves transparency, avoids misleading pictures of progress, and enables more comparable and credible reporting across companies and sectors. To do this, a value chain perspective is needed to ensure all FLAG emissions are accounted across upstream and downstream activities, in order to avoid the risk of them being lost into broader corporate emissions totals, making it difficult to apply removals appropriately or to reflect the distinct mitigation dynamics of land-based systems. This approach is especially important given the limited and evolving guidance on corporate-level inventories for agriculture, forestry, and other land-use (AFOLU) activities.  

At the product level, the distinction becomes even more critical. For many products, particularly agricultural commodities, food, apparel, and bio-based materials, land use change and land management emissions dominate the product's carbon footprint. Without clear FLAG attribution, product claims can become misleading; comparisons across suppliers and materials lose validity, and the climate benefits of bio-based materials or regenerative practices may be obscured. Explicit identification of FLAG emissions  is therefore essential for credible product carbon footprints, meaningful supplier engagement, and alignment between product level claims and corporate transition strategies. 

 What is Science Based Targets initiative framework for Forest, Land and Agriculture (SBTi FLAG) 

The Science Based Targets initiative framework for Forest, Land and Agriculture (SBTi FLAG) guidance provides a dedicated framework for setting science-based targets that address emissions and removals from forests, land, and agriculture, alongside a company’s near-term and long-term climate targets. It clarifies which emissions fall within the FLAG boundary, how land-based emissions and removals should be accounted for, and how companies are expected to demonstrate progress over time in a way that reflects the biological and physical realities of land systems. 

Under the SBTi FLAG, companies are required to set a FLAG-specific target separate from other emissions targets when either of these conditions is met: 

  1. Sector-based requirement: Companies operating in SBTi-designated FLAG sectors, including forest and paper products, food production (animal source), food and beverage processing, food and staples retailing, and tobacco. 
  1. Emissions-threshold requirement: Companies in any sector whose FLAG-related emissions exceed 20% of total gross emissions across scopes 1, 2, and 3. This threshold must be assessed on a gross basis and cannot be netted against removals. 

When a FLAG target is required, companies must report emissions and removals across clearly defined categories that reflect distinct land-based processes: 

  • Land-use change emissions: Refers to CO2 released from carbon stock losses due to the conversion of land between land use categories, such as deforestation for cropland expansion. 
  • Land management emissions: Refers to both CO2 and non-CO2 gases arising from practices within the same land-use category, including tillage, cropping systems, livestock management, and rice cultivation. 
  • Carbon storage and removals: Refers to CO2 removed from the atmosphere through biological processes such as photosynthesis and stored in long-lived biogenic carbon pools such as forest biomass and soils. 

 To ensure transparency and comparability, companies setting FLAG targets are expected to provide disaggregated information that enables meaningful interpretation and review. This includes: 

  •  FLAG emissions and removals reported per commodity and per region 
  •  Separation of land-use change and land management emissions 
  •  Separate reporting of CO2 and non-CO2 emissions from land management activities 
  •  Removals reported by commodity, with further disaggregation across scope 1 and scope 3 categories encouraged 

 These reporting expectations align with the GHG Protocol Land Sector Guidance and the SBTi FLAG Annex submission requirements, supporting consistent and credible treatment of land-based emissions across corporate inventories. 

That’s where our new SBTi FLAG feature comes in. 

 SAP Sustainability Footprint Management for SBTi FLAG 

To facilitate detailed external reporting, especially frameworks like SBTi FLAG that require specific categorization of impacts, SAP's Sustainability Footprint Management introduces a powerful multi-impact category feature. This enables you to map calculated impact category results directly to relevant reporting categories, ensuring alignment with SBTi FLAG requirements. 

For this use case, the integration and calculation setup follow the same procedure as described in our "Multi-Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management" blog post. For SBTi FLAG, the process utilizes your ERP data to automate activity data collection, map to emission factors for the relevant impact categories, and execute one centralized footprint calculation. The critical difference is ensuring that the relevant impact categories for FLAG are selected during the Footprint Inventory setup. 

Here, you'll define the boundaries and specific impact categories to be assessed in your environmental footprint calculation. This step is crucial for FLAG reporting and the following categories must be selected: 

  • Fossil GHG Emissions from Land Management 
  • Biogenic Non-CO2 Emissions 
  • Land Use Change Biogenic CO2 Emissions 
  • Land Management Biogenic CO2 Removals 

Additionally, Climate Change is always calculated as a mandatory impact category in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management; you can also choose to calculate additional categories, like abiotic resource depletion, in parallel with the FLAG analysis. 

For details, see Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes. 

You also need to ensure the inclusion of impact factors for the relevant categories using the Manage Emission Factors app. Each impact category requires a specific emission/impact factor. When populating either the LCA or Simple Template, input a separate entry for each category, even if they relate to the same product, energy source, or business activity, as they are distinguished by distinct Impact Category IDs. 

For SBTi, you must include the following categories are included via data packages: 

  • Fossil GHG Emissions from Land Management (CCFL) 
  • Biogenic Non-CO2 Emissions (CLCN) 
  • Land Use Change Biogenic CO2 Emissions (CLCLU) 
  • Land Management Biogenic CO2 Emissions (CLCM) 
  • Land Management Biogenic CO2 Removals (RELM) 

Climate Change (CLCH) impact factors must also be added, as this category is always mandatory in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Consuming apps like Manage Purchase Products Footprints, Model Energy Flows, Manage Waste Footprints, or Manage Business Activities will utilize these factors for relevant calculations. 

For detailed guidance on maintaining emission factors data, see Emission Factors Data. You'll find a table under Impact Categories, listing all categories, including their IDs, dimensions, and indicators. 

Aside from the impact categories being reported, other calculation parameters like master data, energy flow models, and periodic data remain unchanged. This ensures you can effortlessly scale calculations across different impact categories, allowing existing setups to smoothly adapt and include these additions 

For analyzing the calculated footprints, the Footprint Overview app offers a high-level summary of your impact calculation results, while the Corporate Balance app provides a consolidated view of your organization’s environmental performance. The Purchased Products analytics app now allows display of calculated footprints by impact category using a filter option. 

While the initial dashboards emphasize the Climate Change impact category, clicking on them allows for further detailed analysis. See Using the Footprint Overview Application for more information. 

The Corporate Balance app provides an overarching summary of your organization’s environmental performance. For more on viewing organizational emissions, see Using the Corporate Balance Application. 

The Purchased Products analytics app now provides a detailed understanding of the environmental burden associated with specific procured products across all selected impact categories, offering a richer perspective beyond CO2e. For more insights, see Using the Purchased Products Application. 

Map Calculation Results to Reporting Standards 

The Impact Categories from Sustainability Footprint Management are designed to be standard-agnostic, serving as building blocks for supporting multiple reporting standards simultaneously. This versatility, however, requires final results to be mapped to the appropriate reporting categories for the chosen standard. The following table illustrates this:

entry.title: A simplified approach to choosing between S/4HANA Public Cloud vs S/4HANA Private Cloud
entry.content:
One of the fundamental decisions that organisations are facing as they plan their transition to Cloud ERP, is the deployment option to choose. In SAP terms the question becomes: Would S/4HANA Public Cloud or S/4HANA Private Cloud be the better choice?

At high level, S/4HANA Public Cloud is a "ready-to-run" solution prioritizing standardization and deployment speed, while S/4HANA Private Cloud is a "tailored-to-fit" solution enabling flexibility and customization. In reality, the selection between the two is more complex with different parameters to consider. This article aims to ease the decision process through a simplified approach.

The right deployment option could, and most often should, be subject to a series of workshops and careful assessment of an organisation's specific needs. Still, experience from customer engagements has enabled me to develop a simplified approach which helps provide initial steering.

Overall, where possible, S/4HANA Public Cloud should be the ultimate destination. This due to its unique qualities, including faster access to innovation, a simpler Cloud operating model and reduced Total Cost of Ownership (TCO). On the flip side, Public Cloud also comes with limitations as compared to S/4HANA Private Cloud. These include a narrower implementation scope, reduced system control and the need to leave customisations and certain data behind.

To simplify the decision, as a rule of thumb an organisation should opt for S/4HANA Public Cloud if the following three elements match their needs:

  • S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation scope. Public Cloud offers  broad functionality covering the needs of most organizations and is becoming constantly richer in scope. Still, some functionality such as industry-specific scenarios may be unique to Private Cloud. The way to confirm that Public Cloud vs Private Cloud is fit for purpose is by completing the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment in collaboration with SAP or your Partner.
  • New implementation as migration option. A migration to Public Cloud can be completed only via a new implementation, while a migration to Private Cloud can also be completed via a system conversion or Selective Data transition for organisations on a legacy SAP ERP system. If you are new to SAP, then a new implementation is your clear way forward. If you are moving from a legacy SAP ERP system though, then it is key to validate that a new implementation is right for you. A new implementation requires that custom code and custom processes from your legacy SAP ERP system are left behind - which could actually be an opportunity for moving to a Clean Core and reinventing business processes using SAP's Best Practices. A new implementation also requires that previous transactional data aka closed items are left behind e.g. archived, otherwise maintained in the legacy ERP system (online as read-only or offline as a backup/image). Unless there is a specific need to bring closed items to the new Cloud ERP environment, leaving these behind helps run a lighter, easier to maintain and more cost-efficient system.
  • Public Cloud Operating model. Public Cloud is equivalent to SaaS, as opposed to Private Cloud which is similar to IaaS/PaaS. This means that Public Cloud is highly standardised, enabling rapid innovation at a lower TCO, offering a Clean Core and SAP‑controlled operations and allowing the customer to focus on what matters to them most. It comes with Application Management Services included, therefore, among others, SAP is taking care of  application management including release updates and Middleware. Still, in Public Cloud, extensibility options are limited (classic ABAP extensibility not possible), the customer has no control over release upgrades (these are mandatory without the option to postpone and with a time-restricted regression testing window), and has no control over infrastructure choices either (no Hyperscaler selection). If the organisation has a particular requirement for any of these or for an overall operating model of shared responsibility with SAP, then Private Cloud might be better suited.

    While the above three elements focus mostly on the technical aspects of the deployment option decision, it comes without saying that the company's culture is also a major decisive factor. The appetite to reimagine processes and outsource a large part of IT operations to the software vendor while re-focusing on innovation activities, are of paramount importance for a Public Cloud deployment.

    All that said, the value and fit of Private Cloud for certain organisations should not be overlooked. Many enterprises, especially those with regulatory constraints, multi‑layered integrations, high customisation, heavy data volumes, or deep industry-specific implementation scope, continue to find Private Cloud more practical and in cases the only suitable option.

    To summarise, if you are an organisation planning a transition to SAP’s Cloud ERP and considering your deployment option, your actionable next steps are as follows: complete the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment to confirm whether the scope of S/4HANA Public Cloud matches your functionality needs, evaluate whether a new implementation vs system conversion is fit for purpose, and assess whether the Public Cloud operating model suits you. If the answer to all three questions is yes, and you establish the right company culture, then lead with S/4HANA Public Cloud. Otherwise, in case of unique requirements and a more complex landscape, S/4HANA Private Cloud might be a better fit. 

    Disclaimer: The approach suggested in this article reflects my views based on experience from working with different organizations, rather than SAP's official views. It aims to provide simplified guidelines and initial steering, but does not replace the need for more thorough assessment.

entry.title: SAP Commerce Cloud Q4 ‘25 Release Highlights
entry.content:
As we closed out 2025, SAP Commerce Cloud continued its momentum with a powerful set of innovations designed to deliver connected, trusted, and intelligent commerce experiences that drive profitable growth.​ 

Q4 2025 brought impactful enhancements across commerce, data, AI, fulfillment, and user experience—combined with standout performance results from Cyber Week and recognition once again in the Gartner® Magic Quadrant™. 

Let’s dive into the top updates from Q4 2025. Join our Q4 2025 Release Highlights webcast and the tech-focused update webcast to stay updated on our latest advancements. 

Learn more about the entire SAP Customer Experience portfolio and the impact of agentic AI.

SAP Commerce Cloud named Leader in Gartner Magic Quadrant for Digital Commerce for 11th year in a row 

SAP has proudly been named a Leader in the 2025 Gartner Magic Quadrant for Digital Commerce. SAP remains the only vendor consistently recognized 11 times since 2014. 

This continued leadership reflects SAP Commerce Cloud’s ability to help organizations scale, innovate, and drive profitable growth in an increasingly competitive market. Key differentiators that set SAP Commerce Cloud apart include its robust B2B selfservice portal with native ERP integration, its broad enterprisegrade capabilities, and its proven support for complex and sophisticated business models. 

SAP Commerce Cloud - Cyber Week Results 

SAP Commerce Cloud delivered outstanding results again during the recent Cyber Week The platform supported $17.8 billion in Gross Merchandise Value (GMV), a 40% year over year increase, and reached a peak throughput of $2.3 billion GMV per minute with 11,000 orders processed per minute. Impressively, all of this was achieved with 100% uptime, underscoring the reliability and resilience of the platform during the highest demand period of the year. These results highlight the strength of SAP Commerce Cloud in helping customers scale to meet shopper expectations during critical moments. 

With agentic AI reshaping how customers discover and shop, explore why “2025 is the Last Year Online Shopping Starts with a Search Bar, Not a Sentence.” 

 

Accelerating Customer Value with Enterprise Grade AI Agents 
 
As agentic AI becomes increasingly central to commerce, SAP is expanding its portfolio of intelligent, task‑oriented agents designed to improve engagement, streamline operations, and enhance service at every stage of the customer journey.  

Below are the latest updates to our AI agent capabilities, beginning with the Digital Service Agent. 

The Digital Service Agent elevates customer self service by delivering fast, accurate support powered by enterprise specific knowledge and data sources. It efficiently resolves complex customer inquiries and can seamlessly hand off conversations to human agents whenever deeper assistance is required, ensuring a smooth and consistent service experience. 
 

Working in tandem with the AI Shopping Agent, the Digital Service Agent unlocks new, end to end use cases that provide even greater value. Together, these agents offer customers unified, intelligent assistance across the entire shopping journey—from initial product exploration to post purchase support—improving satisfaction while reducing operational effort. 

Digital Service Agent 

 

Create custom AI agents with Joule Studio AI agent bulder 

 
With the new Joule Studio AI agent builder, you can now create AI agents for SAP Customer Experience applications that retrieve information, execute tasks, and perform autonomous actions using enterprise data from SAP Customer Experience and SAP Knowledge Graph. For example, you can build a returns processing agent that automatically initiates return execution based on insights and recommendations generated by the AI.

Joule Studio, part of SAP Build, offers a powerful lowcode and nocode environment that enables developers to extend Joule capabilities and orchestrate business workflows across both SAP and non SAP systems. From here, teams can easily build, test, and deploy AI agents to enhance operational efficiency and deliver more intelligent customer experiences. 
 
Learn how to activate Joule Studio and start building, testing, and deploying AI Agents. 

 

Joule Studio AI agent builder

 

Turn Live Commerce Data into a Competitive Advantage 

SAP Commerce Cloud Dashboards (Graph Analytics Micro App), is an SAP-certified micro app that is built on SAP Business Technology Platform, providing businesses with instant access to real-time operational insights without the need for complex setup or custom development.  

 

This lightweight yet powerful micro app delivers dynamic dashboards that visualize key commerce metrics including revenue, orders, returns, repeat purchase rates, top performingproducts, and more. By centralizing these insights in a single, intuitive interface, teams can make faster and more informed decisions based on live data. With clearer visibility into trends and performance drivers, businesses can identify growth opportunities, optimize promotions and product strategies, and ultimately boost revenue through data-driven decision making. 

 

Enhance Security and Efficiency with User Management via Cloud Portal API 

User Management via Cloud Portal API enables organizations to manage user roles for an SAP Commerce Cloud environment. By exposing user and role management capabilities through secure APIs, teams can integrate these operations directly into their existing CI/CD and enterprise workflows. This reduces repetitive configuration steps and enhances security and compliance through audit ready role assignments and changes.  

 

Resilient Backup and Recovery with Quick Data Backup 

Quick Data Backup simplifies database protection by providing near-instant backup capabilities and 35-day point in- time recovery across development, stage, and production environments. This solution ensures that businesses can safeguard critical data with confidence and can significantly minimize downtime during incidents. The feature is designed for seamless compatibility with existing workflows, reducing operational friction. With Quick Data Backup, teams gain a reliable, efficient, and resilient foundation for data protection across the entire Commerce Cloud landscape. 

 

Fast In-Memory Cart for High Traffic Commerce 

The Rapid Cart Calculation capability introduces a major performance boost to SAP Commerce Cloud by processing all price and cart calculations directly in server memory. This delivers exceptionally fast response times, especially for high traffic storefronts and scenarios such as product detail page price checks. The in-memory cart not only enhances the customer experience with instant, seamless cart interactions but also significantly reduces backend load, improving overall system scalability and stability. 

 

 This approach supports massive throughput—enabling millions of cart calculation requests per hour—ensuring that even the most demanding commerce environments can maintainconsistent performance during major events like flash sales, seasonal peaks, and promotional campaigns. 

 

Optimize Delivery Performance with Bringg 

Bringg Delivery Management Integrates with SAP Order Management to streamline fulfillment and optimize last mile delivery. With this integration, businesses can offer flexible delivery options, providing customers with real-time tracking updates and proactive notifications across channels. Operationally, automated dispatching reduces manual effort and helps ensure on time delivery, even during peak periods. The result is a faster, more reliable delivery experience that boosts customer satisfaction while improving efficiency and margins. 

 

Assess Your Readiness to Headless Commerce 

The Storefront Maturity Assessment, a free self-service online tool, enables customers to evaluate their organization’s readiness to transition from Accelerator-based storefronts to modern headless architectures. The tool generates personalized, best practice recommendations tailored to each customer’s starting point, helping teams understand where they excel and where additional preparation or alignment is needed. 

 

 This shared assessment framework allows business and technical stakeholders to align priorities and create a unified transformation roadmap. With actionable insights into capability gaps and readiness markers, organizations can accelerate their headless adoption journey, improve pipeline planning, and ultimately enhance the quality and predictability of their digital transformation initiatives.

Custom KPI creation

Account Plan Type configuration 

SAP Customer Loyalty Management: Stronger Connections for Business Growth

The recently launched SAP Customer Loyalty Management helps customers drive long-term relationship development and business growth. The solution captures customer data and loyalty engagement in a cloud-based wallet that acts as a “loyalty profile”, to better understand individual customer motivations and enhance segmentation and targeted marketing campaigns.

Integration with SAP Cloud ERP Private and SAP Business Suite ensures visibility into loyalty-related financial metrics, helping organizations measure ROI and guide future investments. Marketing teams can track promotion performance, redemption rates, and liabilities, enabling them to scale loyalty strategies effectively within existing enterprise systems.


SAP Customer Loyalty Management 

AI Innovations Driving Commerce Forward

AI Shopping Agent

Stock awareness is built in, giving merchants control over whether out-of-stock items appear in recommendations. This transparency reduces cart abandonment and improves customer confidence. For B2B scenarios, merchants can also enable bulk stock inquiries, ensuring buyers get accurate availability for large orders.  


AI Shopping Agent 

Catalog Optimization Agent 

This agent reviews product images and suggests improvements to boost discoverability and conversions. A human review step ensures quality before updates go live, reducing manual effort while maintaining brand integrity.

Digital Service Agent  

Enhance the customer self-service experience and increase contact center efficiency by providing swift, informed support grounded in business knowledge from specific data sources to answer questions. Digital Service Agent addresses complex customer queries, seamlessly transitioning to human agents when needed. 

Digital Service Agent works with AI Shopping Agent, covering new use cases that deliver even more customer value. With both agents, customers benefit from unified support throughout their entire shopping journey, including assistance with post-sale requests.  


Digital Service Agent 

Joule Studio AI agent builder capability 

You can now create AI agents for SAP CX applications to retrieve information, complete tasks, and run autonomous actions using enterprise data from SAP Customer Experience and SAP Knowledge Graph. For example, a returns agent can be built to trigger returns execution based on insights and recommendation from the AI Agent on returns pending approval.

Joule Studio, part of SAP Build, provides developers with a comprehensive suite of low-code, no-code tools to easily extend Joule capabilities and orchestrate business workflows, including CX across SAP and non-SAP applications. Learn how to activate Joule Studio and start building, testing, and deploying AI Agents. 

B2B Self-Service Portal Empowers Customers with 24/7 Access 

Designed as an SAP Cloud ERP add-on, the SAP B2B Self-Service Portal offers post-purchase transparency without the complexity of a full commerce implementation. Launch in weeks using partner packages, then scale to SAP Commerce Cloud without data migration. Buyers gain real-time access to orders, delivery status, and invoices—reducing support overhead and improving satisfaction. 


B2B Self-Service Portal 

Reduce Payment Integration Complexity with Open Payment Framework 
Now extended for B2B transactions, this framework delivers secure, streamlined payment experiences with built-in validation, error handling, and feature toggles. Support for both account-based and digital payment options ensures flexibility—all managed centrally. 

Drive Conversions with Smarter Search Experiences

Helping customers find the right product quickly is key to boosting sales and improving satisfaction. Search Service is designed to deliver precision and flexibility, offering features that elevate product discovery: 

  • Customizable Indexing and Scoring – Fine-tune search results to align with your business priorities
  • Intelligent Spell Correction & Suggestions – Turn typos into successful searches with smart word recommendations
  • Variant Grouping – Present related product variations together for a cleaner, more intuitive experience
  • Configurable Search Bar – Adapt the look and feel of your search interface to match your brand identity 

Pair it with Intelligent Selling Services to unlock AI-powered search capabilities—delivering personalized results, trending suggestions, and intent-driven recommendations that convert.  


Search Service

Streamlined Integrations for Pricing and Enhanced S/4 HANA-based Order Management  

Managing pricing and promotions just got easier! With the latest SAP S/4HANA integrations, SAP Commerce Cloud users can now handle product pricing and order value calculations accurately and consistently from one centralized location.

  • B2B Price Calculation – SAP Variant Configuration and Pricing applies backend pricing rules while handling cart calculations independently, reducing system load. Define product models and pricing rules once and apply them universally
  • Omnichannel Promotions – Leverage SAP Omnichannel Promotion Pricing to create multi-code coupons for targeted campaigns across SAP Customer Experience solutions like SAP Emarsys, delivering personalized offers that boost sales, loyalty, and brand awareness.  

 Order Management with SAP S/4HANA enhances visibility and saves time. 

  • With SAP S/4HANA order integration, attached documents like product specifications or special instructions, along with detailed status information from SAP S/4HANA document flow, are now visible directly in order history. Furthermore, synchronizing products from SAP S/4HANA to display in order history and order details is no longer required. Customers benefit from a comprehensive, 360-degree view of orders, including those not submitted through SAP Commerce Cloud and those containing products not listed in the SAP Commerce Cloud catalogue. 

New APIs Deliver Smarter Self-Service and Automation

We have introduced powerful APIs to simplify operations, reduce manual effort, and improve efficiency: 

  • Scaling Configuration API – Automate sandbox scaling to save consumption credits and reduce errors. Retrieve current scaling, schedule environment actions like hibernation or wake-up, and enforce off-hours policies through scripts—giving DevOps teams greater control
  • Cloud Portal API – Manage dozens of endpoints effortlessly. Programmatically control configurations, including Maintenance Mode, and automate maintenance toggles across environments for faster, error-free operations
  • SSL Certificate Management API – Eliminate manual certificate swaps with automated updates via API. Integrate with your CA/SCM for faster processes, fewer mistakes, lower outage risk, and scalable governance.  

Event Notifications Framework with Guaranteed Delivery 

Integrating with your preferred systems is easier than ever thanks to our configurable Event Notifications Framework. Choose from over 140 prebuilt events—including Order Placed, User Account Deleted, Product Reviewed, and more—covering transactional, user, and backend activities. 

Set up real-time messaging to third-party systems using Webhooks in Backoffice, complete with a visual configurator that minimizes custom coding and maximizes flexibility. 

To ensure critical updates never get lost, we have introduced At-least-once delivery (ALOD). This feature automatically retries failed webhook transmissions, guaranteeing that essential events are delivered at least once and protecting your most important data.  


Webhook Events with At Least Once Delivery enabled 

Flexible Purchasing with B2B PunchOut for Composable Storefront 

B2B PunchOut gives buyers a smooth way to browse a supplier’s online catalog and transfer selected items directly into their procurement system as a requisition. The process includes automatic login and logout for a frictionless experience. 

With PunchOut integrated into the Composable Storefront, the shopping cart becomes the foundation for creating a purchase requisition. This requisition is then routed for internal approval within the buyer’s organization. Once approved, the order flows back to the supplier’s site for processing. There’s no traditional checkout button—instead, when you’re ready, simply click “Back to Requisition” to finalize the transaction in your procurement system.  


Shopping cart page in PunchOut session  

Unlock Data Quickly with SQL View Gateway  

SQL View Gateway gives customers self-service access to SAP Commerce Cloud data, making analytics, reporting, and integrations faster and more efficient—helping you turn insights into smarter decisions. 

Our new real-time database replicas provide direct SQL access, so you can build dashboards, trigger internal workflows, feed data into lakes, and more—all without impacting your production environment

Cut Costs with Non-Production Environment Hibernation

Take control of your commerce operations by hibernating non-production environments whenever you don’t need them—safely and without any risk of data loss or recovery issues. You can even schedule hibernations, for example, after finishing a performance test campaign. The result? Significant cost savings, smarter resource allocation, and stronger security and compliance.  

We rolled out a self-service option that lets you trigger hibernation directly from the Cloud Portal or via API—no need to involve SAP support. It’s a simple way to make your IT infrastructure more efficient, secure, and cost-effective. 

Seamless Omnichannel Transactions with SAP Order Management Services 

The Central Order Service in SAP Order Management Foundation lays the groundwork for true omnichannel experiences. It seamlessly connects online and offline transactions, enabling scenarios such as BORIS (Buy Online, Return in Store) and BISRO (Buy in Store, Return Online) for maximum flexibility. Businesses also gain a 360-degree view of customer purchase histories, driving deeper personalization and engagement. 

The rollout of API V3 significantly improves scalability and performance, ensuring SAP Order Management Foundation can meet the demands of modern commerce environments. 

The new Availability Push feature for SAP Order Management for Sourcing and Availability proactively delivers up-to-date stock information to external systems like web shops and marketplaces. This reduces order cancellations caused by outdated data. Updates can be tailored by channel, product, and frequency, sending only changes in stock levels for efficient communication. 

The Type Code feature in SAP Omnichannel Sales Transfer and Audit introduces robust validation for ERP type codes. Customers can configure acceptable codes, preventing invalid entries from being processed and halting transactions until corrections are made—ensuring data integrity and compliance. 

Upskill Employees with WalkMe Adoption Platform  

With WalkMe Premium for SAP CX, users receive real-time, role-based guidance and automation within SAP CX solutions, such as SAP Commerce Cloud. The embedded training and contextual help simplify complex workflows, accelerates onboarding, and ensures consistent execution. Organizations improve user adoption and unlock more value in their SAP CX investment.  

Partner Solutions Driving Innovation 

Our expanding partner ecosystem on the SAP Store continues to strengthen SAP Commerce Cloud with powerful solution extensions.

Newstore brings a mobile-first, SAP-ready solution with pre-built integrations across SAP commerce offerings to deliver faster, smarter service in retail stores. Its intuitive associate app streamlines workflows, reduces hardware dependency, and seamlessly connects digital and in-store experiences. From store fulfillment to task management and personalized service, Newstore helps retailers optimize operations in high-touch environments.  


NewStore  

Revers.io extends SAP Order Management Services to enhance returns and post-sales processes. This pre-composed solution simplifies returns, repairs, and product reuse, offering an integrated self-service experience. Automated workflows across the after-sales chain reduce lead times, cut reverse logistics costs, and ease customer service workloads—all while accelerating time-to-market. 

Looking Ahead: 2026 and Beyond 

The innovations we delivered in 2025 underscore SAP’s commitment to helping businesses stay ahead in a rapidly evolving landscape. As we move into 2026 and beyond, our priority remains clear: delivering solutions that create measurable value, scale effortlessly, and enable frictionless customer experiences.  

Together, we’re shaping the next chapter of commerce and consumer industries. 
Here’s to an exciting journey ahead and wishing you a joyful holiday season and a successful new year!

entry.content:
This blog covers installation of (1) SAP S/4HANA server and (2) SAP NW JAVA / ADS server as shown in the graphic below. The installation is based on file restore and is different from the standard installs using SWPM.

Please refer to S/4HANA SQUARE ONE for other blogs

In this blog the procedure is simplified for hostname change and SID change. Also if you want to change instance number the command, screens show where you can change the instance number. This would make sense if your network cannot accommodate the unique hostname and SID. Also if it is a more permanent installation you may like to change SID and hostname.

If you want to do standard installation with no change in hostname and sid please refer to other blog In this blog the procedure is simplified for standard installation with NO HOSTNAME OR SID CHANGE. The advantage with this is that you don't have to do many of the steps related to SID change and it does make sense if you will be installing the instance temporarily.

This blog is based on a fresh installation of SUSE Linux for SAP OS without having any previous SAP instances created and deleted. I did not have to pre install hostagent, etc. There are mount points/links to be setup as shown in the right place in the directory structure. The steps in the guides provided with SAP Note 2041140 could be used as a reference in case there are issues specific to your environment. Just follow the steps below to install both systems shown in red square below:

Please find below the main note for ordering the appliance:
2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

PART1: SOFTWARE DOWNLOAD

Please download the software media from https://me.sap.com/softwarecenter
INSTALLATIONS & UPGRADES => By Alphabetical Index (A-Z) => S => SAP S/4HANA => SAP S/4HANA 2025 => S/4HANA FULLY-ACTIVATED APPLIANCE => SAP S/4HANA 2025 FA APPL

On SAP S/4HANA Server, download the 51059242_1 to 51059242_5  files and SWPM20SP22_5-80003424.SAR (or later).

On SAP NW JAVA / ADS server, download the 51059242_5, SWPM10SP45_4-20009701.SAR and 51050829_JAVA_part 1 & 2 - NW 7.5 Java based SW Comp.

PART2: INSTALL SAP S/4HANA

STEP 1: PREPARE SYSTEM Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. For /sapmnt provide min 30GB, /hana/data space - min 500GB, /hana/log min 120GB. I have used /sapmedia - 200GB temporary separate mount that can be removed later.

Plan the change of SID, hostname, instance number. Please refer to the notes below for reserved SIDs SAP Note 1979280 - Reserved SAP System Identifiers (SAPSID) with Software Provisioning Manager and hostnames SAP Note 611361 - Hostnames of SAP ABAP Platform servers
The table below shows standard SID and hostnames and what we are changing it to.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below. If you are changing hostname for db and sap add the standard and new hostname for DB but for SAP only provide new hostname. Also for J2E include the new hostname only as this is on separate instance. The standard hostname can be removed later as shown in the steps below. Please note that it has

STEP 2: EXTRACT FILES Extract files 51059242_*  in /sapmedia

sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_1.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_2.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_3.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_4.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_5.ZIP

Allow approx 2 hours for extraction.

We will install Central system with DB and App on same server. Please move all *.tgz-* files (from 51059242_1 to 51059242_4) to /sapmedia/51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_1

cd /sapmedia/51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_1
mv /sapmedia/51059242_2/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_2/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51059242_3/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_3/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51059242_4/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_4/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51059242_5/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_5/*.tgz-*   .

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

Please use command below to extract the database related archives:

sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia/# cd 51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_1

cat dblog.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner -zpxvf - -C /

Similarly extract the remaining files:

cat dbexe.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner -zpxvf - -C /
cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner -zpxvf - -C /

It takes about an hour for extraction.

Below two Application related archives may be extracted on a separate app server for distributed installation. These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/S4H and /usr/sap/S4H so if you are changing the SID, then you will have to first extract to SID-S4H and then create links to your own SID like S4D

Then extract the files:
sid-hdd-s4d:/usr/sap #cd 51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_1
cat usrsap_s4h.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner  -zpxvf - -C /
cat sapmnt_s4h.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner  -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: GET PASSWORDS Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_5/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml


Follow this procedure as it is a known issue, please refer SAP Note 2082466 - Known Issues in SAP HANA Platform Lifecycle Management (HDBLCM)  (Issue# 69)

cd /hana/shared/HDB/HDB02/vhcalhdbdb
rm .daemon.ini.swp

vi daemon.ini
Edit section [localsecurestore] to change instances = 0

STEP 4: REGISTER DATABASE 

The HANA DB hdblcm register_rename_system command will rename the filesystem for you according to the new target SID for Hana database instance. HDB => HDD.

Please ensure groupid=1000 is free and groupid=79 are free. Use SAP Note 3686516 for troubleshooting.

Execute HANA database specific steps as below:

sid-hdd-s4d: ##/hana/shared/HDB/hdblcm/hdblcm --action=register_rename_system  --groupid=1000 --lss_groupid=79

TIP: Places where you need to enter data is indicated, rest all are default options. Please note hdblcm now includes rename database host and a separate step with command to rename db host (hdblcm --action=rename_system --hostmap=vhcalhdbdb=vhcalhdddb) is not required. Also a separate step to rename mount points (hdblcm --action=register_rename_system) is not required.

This should bring up the database processes as below

sid-hdd-s4d: #/usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 02 -function GetProcessList

TIP: At this point it is necessary to install the HANA database license as the database will be started in restricted mode.

STEP 5: EXTRACT SWPM Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-hdd-s4d:/install #/sapmnt/S4D/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM20SP22_5-80003424.SAR

STEP 6: RENAME SAP SYSTEM Rename instance using sapinst

sid-hdd-s4d:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_ENFORCE_CRL=false SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcals4dci SAPINST_GUI_HOSTNAME=vhcals4dci 

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:

https://sid-hdd-s4d.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

At screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System S4H and Target System S4D:
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you don't want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen SAP HANA Database Connectivity enter Instance Number 02(or changed number) and Password Appliance__1234. Click on Next.

If you don't install HANA DB license you will get error below. Install license using HANA Studio and continue. License is required if there is a database SID change..

At the screen SAP HANA Database Parameter you can change Schema User , DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM password. Please note it is also optional to change the schema user SAPHANADB password along with DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM users.

At the screen Database Schema accept schema SAPHANADB password and confirm Schema password Xxxxxxxn click on Next.

At the screen Rename Tenant Database click on Next

At the screen Secure Storage for Database Connection select HANA Secure User tore (hdbuserstore) click on Next 

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn
At the screen Secure Storage Key Generation accept radio button – Individual Key (Recommended for Productive Systems) On the Next
At next screen Warning click OK
At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next
At the screen Install License Key keep unchecked Install License Key. Click on Next
TIP: It is much easier to install the license by providing the file than doing it later through the application.
At next screen Cleanup of Encryption Key checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next
At next screen Cleanup of Operating System Users checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next
Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

TIP: In case you get this ERROR:

(1) Error occurs when executing command 'changekey' using the command line tool 'rsecssfx'.

RESOLUTION: Follow SAP Note 2800204 - SSFX-0362: Value file "-" does not start with the UTF-8 byte order mark

Ensure the environment variable LC_CTYPE of the user running sapinst is set as LC_CTYPE=en_US.
Stop the current sapinst and restart it. Continue with the existing option.

(2) You may get Warning below for rename of profile parameter. Found possible references to the source system in the profile directory of the target system /sapmnt/S4D/profile 

After sapinst process is finished you can manually start the SAP instance S4D

sid-hdd-s4d:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 01 -function StartSystem ALL
sid-hdd-s4d:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function StartSystem ALL

After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder and remove temporary links to S4H as well as temporary hostnames.

Standard users are as follows:
HANA DB – Instance 02 SYSTEM /<Master Password> or as you changed in above
Web Dispatcher access : bpinst/Welcome1

STEP 7: POST STEPS Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf => Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Adapt HANA connections in DBACOCKPIT (nothing was required to be done here).

Host name / port in table HTTPURLLOC using tcode httpurlloc

Adapt RFC Connections

ABAP connections:
• LOCAL_RFC
• S4DCLNT100, S4DCLNT200, S4DCLNT400
• S4D_RFC

HTTP connections:
• ADS (pointing to the JAVA server after PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA /ADS)
• LOCAL_HTTP
• LOCAL_HTTPS
• S4FIN_HTTPS

SAP Enable Now Web Assistant enter tCode /UI2/FLP_CUS_CONF

Adapt the Fiori notification URL. enter tCode /UI2/FLP_SYS_CONF

Adapt Enterprise Search

Apply product license keys

Install software product license key: Technical restrictions may apply if you don’t install the license. Use the link to obtain license key.
HANA DB license key can be installed via HANA Studio (Preferences -> License)
In SAP S/4HANA 1909 the license key is installed via SAP logon tCode SLICENSE

Further post-installation checks

Install SAP client tools on your local computers

You can take a full backup and remove the temporary links that were setup for S4H

In client 000 fix transport configuration. Enter tCode SE06 and reinstall CTS transport system, Change originals to S4D, Delete old TMS config, delete old versions of transport routes

Adapt any SAP parameters due to changed SID

The database should be with log mode overwrite and you may like to change that as needed.Please carry out the the other basis steps that are usually done with SID change/System refresh :

SPAD - Spool Administration
SCC4 - Client Administration - Logical System
RZ10- Instance profiles
SP01 - Spool delete old spool requests

PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA / ADS

STEP 1: PREPARE SYSTEM Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. Total filesystem needed is min 70GB for installation.

Plan the change of SID, hostname, instance number. Please refer to the notes below for reserved SIDs SAP Note 1979280 – Reserved SAP System Identifiers (SAPSID) with Software Provisioning Manager and hostnames SAP Note 611361 – Hostnames of SAP ABAP Platform servers

The table below shows standard SID and hostnames and what we are changing it to.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below:

STEP 2: EXTRACT FILES

Extract files 51059242_5.ZIP  in /sapmedia

sid-j2d:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_5.ZIP

We will install Java instance from files in  /sapmedia/51059242_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP32ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

cd /sapmedia/51059242_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP32ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/J2E; /usr/sap/J2E and /sybase/J2E. After these are extracted you can rename the filesystem or remount with changed mount points.

sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat dblog.tgz-*  | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat dbexe.tgz-*  | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat sapmnt_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat usrsap_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: GET PASSWORDS Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51059242_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP32ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml

STEP 4: RENAME MOUNT POINTS You can take a full OS backup at this point and rename mount points or directories to /sybase/J2D; /sapmnt/J2D; /usr/sap/J2D. The old standard mount points do not have to exist. After reboot ensure all new renamed mount points are valid.

STEP 5 EXTRACT SWPM Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-j2d:/install #/sapmnt/J2D/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM10SP45_2-20009701.SAR

STEP 6 RENAME SAP SYSTEM Rename instance using sapinst

sid-j2d:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcalj2dci 

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:

https://sid-j2d.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

At the screen Software Integrity click on Next

At screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System J2E and Target System J2D:
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you don't want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen Database System Type keep the default selection SAP Adaptive Server Enterprise for Business Suite

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn

At the screen Operating System User for SAP Database Administrator enter the password for sybj2d and User ID and Click on Next

At the screen SAP ASE Database System Parameters accept or change ports and Click on Next

At the screen Database User Passwords enter the passwords for user sa, sapsa, sapsso, SAPSR3DB which is Welcome_2Welcome_2. Click on Next

At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next

At the screen Media Browser select the media Package Location and Click on Next

At next screen Cleanup of Operating System Users checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next

Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

After about 10mins, the installation process will stop at this point.

You may get Warning below for rename of profile parameter. Found possible references to the source system in the profile directory of the target system /sapmnt/J2D/profile 

Please take note and proceed.

After the sapinst installation is complete, you can manually start/stop the SAP Java instance J2D using old startsap / stopsap commands

sid-j2d:/install # su - j2dadm
sid-j2d:j2dadm > startsap

To access JAVA server as SAP Netweaver Administrator the URL is:
https://sid-j2d.dummy.nodomain:50000/nwa

Standard users are as follows:
JAVA Administrator – Adminitstrator / <Master Password> ;
Java user BPINST/Welcome1

STEP 7: POST STEPS Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf - Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Apply product license keys if you haven't installed during swpm install step before. Technical restrictions may apply if you don’t install the license. Use the link to obtain license key. SAPNetweaver 7.5 J2EE license key has to be installed via SAP Netweaver Administrator

Further post-installation checks
Adapt any SAP parameters due to changed SID
After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder.

SUPPORT TICKETS:

If you have any difficulty downloading the media open OSS message using component XX-SER-SAPSMP-SWC. If you have issues with technical deployment open message with component BC-INS-SRN.

OTHER REFERENCES:

SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Create your SAP S/4HANA system in a fraction of the usual setup time
SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Demo Guides

Blogs with known issues ( 2025 / 2023 / 2022 / 2021 / 2020), continuously updated

2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

Thank you. Hope you enjoyed the installation.

Mahesh Sardesai
Product Expert – S/4HANA

entry.title: Why Bringing SAP to Agentic SDK via Regular MCP Server Is Not Good Enough
entry.content:
Advocating Technology

Let me name things properly – we have lots of noise around AI. Companies are trying to jump into the technology because they think that Business AI is simple, that it is just a kind of ChatGPT that gets access to business data. Sounds simple, doesn’t it?

I strongly disagree! Bringing SAP data to an Agentic SDK, like Claude or SAP Joule, does not mean delivering Business AI. It is far away from even an understanding of business needs. I know, you start hating me 😊. And the only reason for the internal opinion in your head is that you are most probably one of the MCP bridge providers that think that wrapping APIs (I will not write “discover OData via MCP Server,” because the whole SAP community will hate me :D), or wrapping SAP tables/views, or wrapping SAP function modules is the way to bring SAP data to Business AI. 

How many posts do we see now on LinkedIn where people are happy like kids seeing data from an agentic SDK, e.g. Claude Desktop, returned by OData that is called via an MCP Server and shown as a table. Wow-wow! A list of Purchase Orders! As a table! Based on my utterance! C’mon people, we are not in 2017 when we, together with the SAP Conversational AI team, were happy to see such kinds of cases. Yes, 9 years ago it was innovation, not now. Why not post on LinkedIn that the same OData service draws an even nicer table in a standard SAP Fiori app showing a list of Purchase Orders with… OMG… DRILL DOWN!!! 😊

Why am I writing this? Just to emphasize that Business AI is an excellent technology that is now far beyond strange posts where people see SAP data in another UI than GUI or Fiori. Real Business AI returns investment, works autonomously, and understands data. For example, an AI agent that gets emails from customers with purchase orders from their systems confirming the deals we’ve made with them. That AI agent posts those emails to SAP, creating Sales Orders, for sure not using OData. Why not? Because there are two EntitySet calls you need to do to create a Sales Order via OData, and you need to be able to simulate a batch call; otherwise, you will get lots of Sales Order headers in your SAP productive system when the OData call for Sales Order Items has failed.

 Pic.1 Example from LinkedIn Article – Creating Sales Order via OData without Batch Mode

However, even creating a Sales Order from my example is not the biggest challenge for that AI agent.

The Biggest Challenge

SAP data and the “bridges” we build to connect AI agents with SAP via “regular” MCP servers, this is the biggest challenge we create for AI agents. Sometimes it seems that after allocating a really good business case, we are doing everything possible to push the AI agent to fail 😊.

SAP data preparation is the boring, but extremely essential, step here. We should think about what we feed to the AI agent when asking it to read an email and post a Sales Order in the SAP system. We need to give the AI agent a chance to query master data that is so essential for that AI automation scenario and allocate master data in a robust and reliable way, independent of how the customer names our services and products in their systems.

SAP Master Data Vectorization

Let’s see a simple example we have created using the ChatGPT UI showing how different AI agents will act if you prepare and only then bridge SAP data properly. We will use two MCP servers for this:

  • Regular MCP Server for SAP Data (any MCP server, we do not like to point fingers at someone’s solution; we’d like to advocate AI automation only)

  • Skybuffer AI MCP Server for SAP Data (here we have a data preparation layer where we vectorize SAP master data first)

 Pic.2 SAP Master Data Vectorization as a Data Preparation Step

See the Difference

Now let’s simulate a request from an AI agent that is working autonomously and has responsibility to create Sales Orders in an SAP production system with the maximum level of automation.

Here is a simple example of a regular MCP Server failure, just because the customer captured data in their system a bit differently from our SAP productive system:

Pic.3 Regular MCP Server for SAP Data – Failing on the Simple Case of Small Wording Differences

And now let’s see how easily and robustly an AI agent gets information from the same SAP system, but via an MCP Server that reads prepared SAP master data for AI automation:

 Pic.4 Skybuffer AI MCP Server – Easy and Robust Access to SAP Master Data

Now you see that 99% of all examples or success stories from LinkedIn about how fast we can create MCP servers to bridge SAP data and how reusable OData services are, are solutions that are far away from productive implementation (unless you are OK with getting a 50% automation rate 😊).

Conclusion

Indeed, MCP servers that consume OData, tables/views, etc. make sense for some steps in AI automation. However, we need to be very careful, and we should not mix hype with productive implementations. A good MCP server bridges prepared SAP data that an AI agent can consume to provide a maximal rate of automation that will reach 100% in a short time of productive usage. Saving on implementation ruins the impression of Business AI and reduces trust in it. Let’s not harm our overall revenue and investment return, and think twice whether the bridge we build for an AI agent suits the goal.

Imagine connecting the Skybuffer AI MCP Server to SAP Joule, making it able to understand user input by similarities. How powerful would your SAP Joule implementation be, and how smoothly would SAP Joule understand requests? Skybuffer AI runs on SAP BTP, providing a hidden but necessary layer for SAP Joule that can properly bridge your SAP on-premise data.

Closing Statement

Good luck with AI automation implementations, and do not hesitate to ask questions, collaborate, and bring technology to customers in a way they benefit from it, not just seeing the hype in it.

entry.title: S/4 HANA: In The Era of Intelligent ERP
entry.content:
ERP systems have evolved beyond solely managing and maintaining documents; they now serve as the digital core of the enterprise. SAP S/4HANA marks a new era of intelligent ERP, where real-time data, embedded analytics, and AI-driven automation come together to provide businesses with agility, resilience, and foresight.
 
Transitioning from SAP ECC to S/4HANA: 5 Key Changes to Business Operations
Transitioning from SAP ECC to S/4HANA isn’t simply a technical upgrade; it’s actually a business reset. The primary benefit organizations notice when adopting S/4HANA is the improved processing speed. Real-time processing eliminates batch jobs and enables leaders to base decisions on facts instead of assumptions. Finance closes in days instead of weeks, supply chains adapt faster, and sales teams have better visibility into operations. One thing that doesn’t change enough is your business processes. Moving to S/4 forces companies to question old ways of working that no longer add value. Done properly, it streamlines operations and enhances the user experience for every function. Transformation works when business and IT align and embrace the change together. If one side is left behind, S/4HANA will fail to realize its full potential and instead become a costly replacement. ERP Transformation is less about migrating to new technology and more about changing mindsets.
 
Intelligent ERP as a Decision Engine, Not a Transaction System.
Originally, ERP systems were designed to record past business activities. Intelligent ERP flips the script. Real-time visibility combined with embedded analytics within S/4HANA enables teams to act proactively by breaking data out of silos prior to crises. Inventory shortages? Demand changes? Risky operations? They’re all visible long before they become problems. But it gets better. The business achieves extraordinary success when ERP systems empower leadership teams to make more informed decisions beyond operational management. Fewer lengthy meetings. Less escalate-this! And executable plans that everyone buys into. An ERP designed exclusively for transaction management serves the same limited function as a phone restricted to text messaging capabilities. Intelligent ERP transforms data into a powerful tool that enables informed decision-making. That’s indispensable. That’s intelligent ERP.
 
Supply Chain Visibility in the Age of Real-Time ERP
Supply chains today operate in a world of constant disruption.  Real-time ERP changes how organizations respond. Instead of reacting to delays or shortages, teams gain visibility into risks as they emerge. This enables proactive planning, faster mitigation, and better collaboration across functions. S/4HANA integrates planning, execution, and analytics into a single digital core. The result is not just transparency, but confidence in decision-making. Resilient supply chains are built on visibility, agility, and trust in data. Real-time ERP provides all three. The future of supply chain leadership is insight-driven, not reactive.
 
Omnichannel Availability: The Backbone of Modern Retail
Despite the absence of ERP systems, customers experience the impact daily. Omnichannel availability is no longer just an advantage for retailers; it's now a requirement. Accurate inventory management across multiple channels ensures customer trust and maintains consistent revenue, whether it is done through online channels or through partners. The challenge isn't demand. It's synchronization. The absence of a unified ERP backbone leads to mismatches in inventory, which causes lost sales and operational inefficiencies. The implementation of S/4HANA enables organizations to monitor supply and demand in real-time across all channels, simplifying the process. A seamless inventory movement leads to improved customer experience without any additional complexity.
 
Why most S/4HANA Transformations Often Struggle with Adoption
A significant proportion of S/4HANA programs underestimate the readiness of individuals while prioritizing system readiness. New interfaces, reworked processes, and real-time reporting necessitate that users work differently. Resistance arises when change management is not a priority. Why? Training alone isn't enough. Understanding the reasons behind process changes and their impact on daily work is crucial for users. Effective changes involve effective communication, successful role-based enablement, and sponsorship of leaders from the leadership level on the first day. The ERP's value is not realized until the system is deployed, but only after users have adopted it.
 
The transition from SAP ECC to S/4HANA involves more than just technology; it requires real-time data, optimized processes, and better decision-making. Intelligent ERP helps finance, supply chain, and retail sectors by eliminating data silos and identifying risks early. S/4HANA supports modern needs like supply chain resilience and multi-channel inventory management. Effective business-IT alignment and user adoption are crucial for maximizing transformation benefits.

entry.title: Introducing Partial Accept in Solution Quotation: A More Flexible Way to Fulfill Customer Outcomes
entry.content:
In today’s outcome‑driven business environment, customers expect solutions not just individual products or services. To support this shift, the Manage Solution Quotation application in On‑Premise and Private Cloud environments enables sales teams to combine multiple item categories into a single, comprehensive solution proposal. This unified quotation allows businesses to sell a complete outcome rather than a set of standalone offerings

When a solution quotation is fully accepted, the system automatically generates the appropriate follow‑up documents for each item category. For example:

  • All Sales Items transfer into a Sales Order
  • Service-related items generate the corresponding Service Orders or Service Contracts
  • Subscription elements create Subscription Contracts

While this automation simplifies downstream processes, it presents a challenge for businesses selling long‑term or phased outcomes. If the full solution is accepted at once, the system creates follow-up documents for the entire item and quantity set. Many customers, however, need the flexibility to fulfill outcomes gradually especially in multi‑phase projects or long-running service engagements.

Available from 2025 FPS0, Partial Accept feature enhances the flexibility and practicality of solution quotations., This enhancement allows customers to:

  • Accept only selected item/s or
  • Accept only a portion of the target quantity of specific items

Each partial acceptance triggers the creation of follow‑up documents only for the accepted scope, leaving the remaining items or quantities available for future acceptance.

Why Partial Accept Matters

The Partial Accept feature empowers businesses to:

  • Support Long-Term or Multi-Stage Solutions: Customers can use a single solution quotation over an extended period, accepting portions as needed.
  •  Manage Delivery and Fulfillment Flexibly: Instead of generating all follow-up documents at once, businesses can create them in stages aligned with their operational or customer timelines.
  •  Improve Outcome-Based Selling: When selling outcomes rather than discrete products, staged acceptance aligns better with real-world project progress.

Here is an Illustration how to use partial accept

Prerequisite Customising To use this feature set the Multiple References field to Yes under Customizing , Service->Transactions->Basic Settings->Define Item Categories for all relevant item categories.

Now you can use, first create solution quotation, including relevant target quantities of items, here you see new disabled button "Partially Accept" and new column "Released Quantity"

Once you saved and released all items, same like 'Accept' button, 'Partial Accept' button will also be enabled 

On clicking the Partial Accept button, a dialog window opens where the user can select the items and the required quantities they want to partially accept.

For example, based on your business requirements, you may choose to select only Sales Items, Spare Parts, and Service Items. Instead of accepting the full quantity (10), you can partially accept a target quantity of 2 for the selected items.

 
This Partial Accept will create respective follow-up documents Sales Order and Service  with 2 quantity of selected items

Now, using this flexibility, you are requested to create a sales order for line item 60 (a different sales item compared to item 10). Click the Partial Accept button again. In the same dialog window, you will notice that the target quantities of the previously accepted items have been reduced.

Next, select line item 60 and specify a partial quantity of 2 units. This action will create a new sales order (4743), rather than adding the item to the previously created sales order (4742).

in Transaction History you can see new sales order created, navigate and see the created sales order.

Again, as per your business requirement, you want to create a sales order with a few more quantities, this time, 1 unit of the sales item and a service order with 1 unit of the service item. Previously, we entered 2 units, leaving 8 units remaining. Now, we are going to enter 1 unit for both items, as shown in the image below.

On Accept it will create new sales order and service order document with respective items with 1 unit of quantity.

Similarly, the same approach can be applied to other items by leveraging Solution Quotation not only for selling bundles, but also for effectively managing solution items and their fulfillment with greater flexibility. By adopting the partial acceptance capability in your solution business, organizations can enable more controlled decision-making, phased commitments, and improved delivery outcomes.

I welcome your suggestions and feedback on this blog. If you have additional requirements or enhancement ideas, please submit them through the Customer Influence Portal.

What is Model Context Protocol ?

MCP (Model Context Protocol) is an open-source standard for connecting AI applications to external systems.

An MCP server can provide access to  data sources, tools and apps within S4HANA which will enhance capabilities of an AI agent.

It allows an interface to  securely access tools, data and services.

For an ECC / S/4HANA system MCP can provide a solution to certain long-standing problems that customers have.

  • No access to ERP data for AI applications and agents.
  • Provide authorization control on tools and data that can be used.
  • A clean separation between AI application logic and ERP system.

Sample Architecture setup.

Step - by - step building an MCP server.

Let us consider the table SFLIGHT which holds flight connection data.

Create a CDS view and OData service that can expose SFLIGHT data as a REST API call.

Create and Activate the service

Sample entry through the created OData service for SFLIGHT data.

Create an MCP server to access OData service as an MCP tool.

Using FastMCP to create an MCP server that calls an OData service at the backend.

We need to next establish a connection between the on premise S/4HANA system and the MCP server on BTP.

We can accomplish this using the SAP Connectivity service and through cloud connector.

Cloud connector exposed back-end systems are now visible in the BTP cockpit for your account.

Deploy application on BTP.

MCP server is now running on BTP

Visualize the tools available and the MCP server through MCP Inspector.

Create a Basic ReACT agent and bind it with the MCP server.

Running the react agent with the query “Can you get plane type for carrier AA and connection 0017”

Security and Authorization

While the goal of this article is to demonstrate a way to talk to AI agents from legacy data, it is important to note that making business data available comes with risks of data leakage and other security concerns.

Data access governance has to be carefully considered when attempting such an integration by the creator of the MCP server, unrestricted access by third-party agents can pose many security risks which go beyond the scope of this article.
